title: 110_hr389
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dam Rehabilitation and Repair Act of 2007" and focuses on the rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams. The National Dam Safety Program Act is amended to define "Administrator" as the Administrator of FEMA and "deficient dam" as a dam that fails to meet minimum safety standards and poses a risk to the public. The National Dam Safety Program Act is amended to include a definition of "rehabilitation" as the repair, replacement, reconstruction, or removal of a dam to meet State dam safety standards. Additionally, a program for the rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams is added to the Act. The National Dam Safety Program Act is amended to include a definition of "rehabilitation" as the repair, replacement, reconstruction, or removal of a dam to meet State dam safety standards. Additionally, a program for the rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams is added to the Act, under SEC. 8A. The Administrator will establish a program within FEMA to provide grant assistance to States for rehabilitating publicly-owned deficient dams. States can apply for grants by submitting applications to the Administrator, who may award grants for dam rehabilitation projects that meet specified criteria. The Administrator will enter into a project grant agreement with the State to establish terms for the grant and project. A risk-based priority system will be developed for identifying deficient dams eligible for grants. Funds allocated for grants to States will be divided equally among applying States and based on the number of non-Federal publicly-owned dams identified by the Secretary of the Army. The Secretary of the Army will identify dams in the national inventory that pose a danger to human health within the State. The Federal government will fund up to 65% of the rehabilitation cost for deficient dams. Authorization of appropriations includes $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2007 and $100,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2010. The Federal government will provide funding for the employment of additional staff at FEMA to carry out necessary tasks. Sums appropriated for this purpose will remain available until expended. Additionally, the term "Director" in the Act will be replaced with "Administrator". SEC. 3. RULEMAKING. The Administrator of FEMA must issue a proposed rule within 90 days and a final rule within 120 days of this Act's enactment regarding the amendments made.
